abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>NAA10 is the catalytic subunit of the N-terminal acetyltransferase complex, NatA, which is responsible for N-terminal acetylation of nearly half the human proteome. Since 2011, at least 21 different <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> missense variants have been reported as pathogenic in humans. The clinical features associated with this X-linked condition vary, but commonly described features include developmental delay, intellectual disability, cardiac anomalies, brain abnormalities, facial dysmorphism and/or visual impairment. Here, we present eight individuals from five families with five different de novo or inherited <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> variants. In order to determine their pathogenicity, we have performed biochemical characterisation of the four novel variants c.16G>C p.(A6P), c.235C>T p.(R79C), c.386A>C p.(Q129P) and c.469G>A p.(E157K). Additionally, we clinically describe one new case with a previously identified pathogenic variant, c.384T>G p.(F128L). Our study provides important insight into how different <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> missense variants impact distinct biochemical functions of NAA10 involving the ability of NAA10 to perform N-terminal acetylation. These investigations may partially explain the phenotypic variability in affected individuals and emphasise the complexity of the cellular pathways downstream of NAA10.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors have no relevant financial or non-financial interests to disclose.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. The study was approved by the IRBs at the Madigan Army Medical Center (#217122) for family 1, National Committee on Health Research Ethics (protocol nr. CVK-1302181) for family 2, and University of Virginia Health System for family 3 and 4. The next-generation sequencing panel of family 5 was performed in a clinical diagnostic setting.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Written informed consent was obtained from adult participants and legal guardians of child participants. The investigators have adhered to the policies for protection of human subjects as prescribed in 45 CFR 46.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: A full written consent for publication including patient photographs, was provided by the parents.
